awd_titl_txt: Investigation of the Room Temperature Brittle-to-Ductile Transition of Single-Crystal Silicon at Sub-Micron Length Scale Using Accelerated Molecular Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
As is well-known, silicon is brittle so that it shatters on impact. Due to this brittle fracture, silicon-based structures are not machined, but fabricated in a variety of artful ways. Above a critical temperature though, at about 600 °C for bulk silicon, silicon becomes ductile, i.e., it can deform plastically. Several recent experiments have found that sub-micron silicon structures exhibit plastic deformation even at room temperature. While this size-dependent brittle-to-ductile transition has a strong potential to improve the reliability and manufacturability of silicon-based nanotechnology, our current understanding of the phenomenon remains incomplete. The objective of this grant is to achieve a fundamental atomic-level understanding of the size-dependent brittle-to-ductile transition of single-crystal silicon using computational modeling. This will be accomplished by reproducing the experimental observations with atomistic simulations and then analyzing the simulation results and constructing predictive multiscale models. The knowledge and understanding obtained in this research will improve the reliability of the ubiquitous micro- and nano-electro-mechanical systems through better designs as well as cost-efficient manufacturing processes, which will have significant impact on the national economy as the global nanotechnology market is estimated to reach $90.5 billion by 2021. This grant will also be used to engage undergraduates in research by leveraging the women in science and engineering summer research program and the co-op program, respectively, at the University of Cincinnati.

In this study, accelerated molecular dynamics simulations will be performed to unveil the atomic-scale mechanisms responsible for the room-temperature plastic deformation of single-crystal silicon at sub-micrometer scale. Computational models of single-notched blocks and nanowires will be considered to analyze the effects of various key factors such as temperature, size, geometry, loading rate, and free surface structures and oxide layers. To carry out the simulations under near-identical experimental conditions, an accelerated molecular dynamics simulation method called hyperdynamics as well as a spatial multi-scale quasi-continuum method will be employed. The outcomes of this research will enable investigation of other brittle materials such as sapphire and zirconia whose machinability has also been an ongoing issue.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supports a theoretical and simulation study on the brittle-to-ductile transition (BDT) of single-crystal silicon, which exhibits size-dependent behaviors. Silicon, a widely used semiconductor material, is crucial in recent advances in nanotechnology, particularly in the development of MEMS (micro-electro-mechanical systems). Typically, silicon is brittle and shatters upon impact under normal conditions, but it becomes ductile and undergoes plastic deformation at temperatures above a critical threshold. It is known that this brittle-to-ductile transition is influenced not only by temperature but also by the system size, allowing small-scale silicon devices to exhibit ductility even at room temperature. This research aims to explore and understand the fundamental atomic-level mechanisms behind the BDT behavior of single-crystal silicon through modeling and simulation techniques.

We employed molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to model materials by representing their constituent atoms and tracking their dynamic evolution during physical processes. Our MD simulations included single-crystal silicon blocks oriented in various directions and utilized different interaction models between silicon atoms. The focus of these simulations was on understanding the key factors and parameters that lead to different failure behaviors in silicon: either crack development and propagation typical of brittle materials or slip deformations between atomic layers characteristic of ductile materials. We developed and applied several novel simulation tools, such as the nudged elastic band method, to identify the minimum energy path connecting different states of the system, revealing the deformation mechanisms that occur during these transitions. We further examined key parameters such as tensile strength for bond breakage, crack opening, and shear strength for initiating slip deformation, along with the local stress and strain distributions in discrete systems under external loading. The primary conclusion is that the failure behaviors of silicon can be understood as a competition between the buildup of tensile stress leading to bond breakage and the increase in shear stress that initiates glide along slip planes, which strongly depends on the crystal orientation.

Since the global nanotechnology market is estimated hundreds of billions of dollars, the research outcomes can ultimately expedite the development of nanotechnology and thus have significant positive impacts on the national and global economy. The findings have been shared through presentations at scientific and engineering conferences and the manuscripts with the results are being prepared for journal publication. Moreover, this research has provided valuable training and research opportunities for a graduate student and a post-doctoral researcher, as well as supported the involvement of multiple undergraduate students through the University of Cincinnati’s co-op programs. Furthermore, the research outcomes have been incorporated into a graduate-level course taught by the principal investigator, which focuses on modeling and simulations of material systems.
